content.question: A toy water launcher, initially full of water, can slide with negligible friction on a horizontal surface. Water is ejected horizontally from the launcher with a constant speed relative to the launcher. The mass of water ejected from the launcher over any time interval of length <math alttext="delta t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Δ</mtext><mi>t</mi></math> is constant as well. Which of the following statements correctly describes how the launcher moves, if at all, and provides a correct justification?

choices.label: The launcher will remain in place because there is no horizontal force acting on the launcher.
The launcher will move at a constant speed because the water is ejected at a constant speed.

The launcher will move at a constant acceleration because the system of the launcher and remaining water experiences the same impulse during any time interval of length <math alttext="delta t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Δ</mtext><mi>t</mi></math>.

The launcher will move at an increasing acceleration because the mass of the system of the launcher and remaining water is decreasing, and the system experiences the same impulse during any time interval of length <math alttext="delta t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Δ</mtext><mi>t</mi></math>.

content.answer: The launcher will move at an increasing acceleration because the mass of the system of the launcher and remaining water is decreasing, and the system experiences the same impulse during any time interval of length <math alttext="delta t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Δ</mtext><mi>t</mi></math>.

skill.text: 3.C: Justify or support a claim using evidence from experimental data, physical representations, or physical principles or laws.
